job_title: Supervisor in Salisbury, England
pros: Great management, fabulous volunteers a real family feel
cons: Non at all throughly enjoyed my time there

job_title: Fundraiser in London, England
pros: good money, no pressure, ok hours
cons: like most charities, focused on income, which, in turn, pays our wages. as an ex service person, i think they've forgotten the actual 'heroes'

job_title: Events Officer in Salisbury, England
pros: Nice and friendly team. Very transparent.
cons: Office is far away from station so difficult to get to

review_title: Fundraising exec focused on Major Donors and T&F
job_title: Fundraising Manager in London, England
pros: Great driven team with focused long term goal of helping the veteran community
cons: Providing a service in an increasingly competitive area; sometimes the layers of bureaucracy surrounding marketing content creation can lead to significant delays in delivering an appeal or pitch to funders.

review_title: exe team is far too large reduce the headcount and put the savings into to the shop floor workers
job_title: Welfare Worker in Salisbury, England
pros: great team ethos at mid to lower levels
cons: lack of autonomy. exec team doesn't understand the idiosyncrasies of the care support provided.

job_title: Fundraiser in Salisbury, England
pros: Friendly team of people, good salary, gained valuable experience in this role.
cons: No sense of direction or charity goals. Poor management. People in positions based on time at the job rather than their skills or experience. Fundraising is the least of their focus.

job_title: Direct Veteran Support in Catterick, England
pros:
A great cause, especially if you're a veteran or have veteran links. Some fantastic work for the beneficiaries that rely so much on H4H - it was a privilege to be a part of this and hopefully I've added value to many in my short time there. Also a great immediate team. 

Some lovely perks, such as your birthday off and much more leave than what I'm used too. Great WLB and an inspiring CEO.
cons: Some similarities with previous contributors. I'd love to see staff are paid in line with the bracket for the roles, and there is also the hierarchical feel that's also ben mentioned. This makes it really difficult to get included in different projects or tasks outside of your job role, or have any meaningful say in anything that changes your day-to-day working. Unfortunately, there can be a 'stay in your lane' reaction should you put ideas forward....

review_title: Some star employees and some concerns
job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros:
Friendly culture
Potential of diverse opportunities to get involved in
Evolving to an online delivery and community (local) model
Some excellent staff who are very knowledgeable and ethical
cons:
A lot of decisions made at management level and not listening to experience from the ground
Some staff with poor and unethical behaviours and policies to address this are weak or not followed up consistently
Culture of bullying allowed and not addressed, creating sub groups

job_title: Major Gifts in London, England
pros: Great charity to work for. Careful with the pennies, care about the wellbeing of their staff, career development and lots more.
cons: For me the commute to London office, only reason I left.

job_title: Operations Manager in London, England
pros: Seeing first hand the work we do changing lives for the better
cons: Staff not valued by directors

job_title: IT Program Manager in Salisbury, England
pros: Great Cause, Teams are tightknit, Fun
cons:
Shrinking organisation
Still trying to do to much with not enough money or resources

job_title: Manager in Salisbury, England
pros:
Great team members and knowing that we are working towards a common goal of giving veterans a better chance in life post military service.
Flexible on home working when needed and benefits of private health etc after 6 months service an ample bonus.
It is a fun place to work and the ethos is generally this. New ideas very welcomed and you don't feel like a number as I have previoulsy felt in the corporate world.
Every day can be different and I personally like this and sometimes the challenges it can bring. I like the variety also as doing the same thing day-in day-out can lead to mundaneness
cons:
Pay increases are rare these days and in the Charity sector this is reflected on past year's fundraising as we, as the beneficiaries depend on this income coming in. Suffice to say, no pay increase in 18 months service and some have had none in the last 3 years service.
Whilst everyone works as a team they also 'chip' in and seem to think their ideas are better than others. Some departments deem their ideas to be better and are voiced lourder than others to get their say.
Limited room to advance career unless you consider changing into another role availabel within the Charity sometimes. Middle management rarely move on, so the tier under them remain as 'status quo' so there has been a high staff turnover in the last 12-18 months.
Communication from high level management down can be hit or miss - but used to this no matter what company you work for

job_title: Marketing in Salisbury, England
pros: Structure of company, fun work and great Team
cons: poor pay, expected overtime and bad work life balance

review_title: Adaptive Adventures Sports and Sports Coach
job_title: Recreational Adventure Therapist in Loughborough, England
pros: The job is amazing and I get to work on a daily basis with Wounded, Injured and Sick Service personnel using Sport to aid in their physical, psychological and social rehabilitation and recovery. Each day is spent working out how we can adapt normal everyday sporting activities for people to continue to enjoy them as part of a healthy active lifestyle. Sport is such an important part of  service life that without it part of life is missing. Whether that's skiing down a slope in the alps, to kayaking a river, taking part it events such as the Invictus Games or going bowling with your children at the weekend its a huge part of recovery. I am proud to have been a small part of so many peoples recovery journey and look forward to the journeys' yet to come.
cons: Doing the job I do and working is a very small peer team  there is no real opportunity for promotion if that is what you want. There is however lots of opportunity for personal and professional development which off sets this. I do not want a management role so perhaps the downside is enjoying my job so much I do not want promotion?!

job_title: Communications in Colchester, England
pros: I can honestly say this is the best job I’ve ever had. There is a real emphasis on well-being and that makes such a difference to productivity and proactivity. Working within a Recovery Centre means you get to see first hand the positive impact the charity is having on our wounded, injured and sick. Training and development opportunities were second to none. What a fun, friendly and supportive environment to work in. I would highly recommend working at Help for Heroes. I’m only leaving as the Recovery Centre is small. If I wanted to move forwards within the charity then it would mean re-locating.
cons: The charity has undergone many changes in the last year to save money. This has meant a slicker operation, which has worked for the better, but it has been an unsettling time. It has also meant a shift in focus to fundraising Comms from beneficiary Comms which I’m not comfortable with as I don’t feel it uses my skillset to the best of my ability.

review_title: You'll never work with more passionate people
job_title: Head of People Capability in Salisbury, England
pros: Generally, people who work for charities are highly passionate about what they do, but the team at Help for Heroes step this up to the next level!  Hugely motivated, defiantly energetic and utterly committed makes for a contagious workplace that was simply a joy to be a part of.  The work itself is purposed and so many opportunities to grow and develop.  Absolutely loved it!
cons: I don't have any cons to add, as I've simply offered advice to the leadership team below

review_title: It's so much more than just a job.
job_title: Head of Volunteering in Salisbury, England
pros:
At Help for Heroes you get to positively impact peoples lives, every day! You also get to meet the amazing people we help and support. The whole Team H4H ethos is about having this unique opportunity to genuinely make a difference..... and you can get involved too; fundraising, volunteering and generally 'doing your bit'. The staff are fantastic and we all share the common goal; to change lives. 
It's definitely so much more than just a job; it's a vocation and a privilege to be part of!
cons: I can't think of many to be honest....... although, some of the myths and stories that get told and written about H4H are quite damaging and can be a little draining and demotivating....... but we always bounce back!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Downton, South West England, England
pros:
The organisation tries to look after it's staff as well as the people the charity is set up to support. 
Flexible working, hard work but fun as well. I work in IT, the team work hard and are in a very busy programme of change at the moment - in order to fulfill the needs of the charity for the future.  they roll out projects, innovations and upgrades to existing infrastructure and is one of the most dynamic and forward-thinking IT dept i have ever worked for.
Laid-back, friendly culture
free parking
People are quite 'Huggy'
cons:
the commute can be a pain - but the attitude towards flexible working is great
need to be self-motivated to work here
People are quite 'Huggy'

job_title: Senior Regional Manager in Billericay, England
pros: Very rarely working for a charity in a fundraising team do you get the opportunity to see first hand how all your hard work pays off to support the charity's beneficiaries but at Help for Heroes you absolutely get the chance to meet our veterans and hear their stories and how we have helped. This definitely inspires me every day to do my job to the best of my ability. The staff are all so energetic and so passionate about our nations heroes so a great place to work.
cons: I work long hours but I do this out of passion to support our armed forces so its not really a "con".

review_title: A truly fulfilling place to be
job_title: CIO in Downton, South West England, England
pros: A great cause, where you can make a tangible and positive difference. Great people with an energetic and inclusive culture. Interesting and stimulating work supporting diverse activities across recovery, fundraising and trading. An environment of continuous improvement striving for excellence.
cons: A very ambitious change agenda and set of services can leave things stretched at times, but we are all empowered to speak up and help to get the priorities right.

job_title: Sports Recovery Administrator in South Tidworth, England
pros: I feel there is great reward in my work and feel I make a difference in helping our beneficiaries. The interaction with our beneficiaries is second to none and feel this spurs me on to do my best in my role.  I feel I am well looked after at help for Heroes and no problem is too much for them to help with.
cons: I feel some areas are hugely understaffed and can be looked at re-jigging certain areas to compensate for this. I also feel the need for more staff integration as in Staff days whether this be low budget activity based or get togethers.

review_title: Great place to work, very accommodating employer
job_title: Project Lead in London, England
pros: Really flexible with employees requests to achieve work life balance, positively challenging place to work and progress with your career. Whilst making a difference to others by supporting a good cause.
cons: Internal communications is improving however there is still a little way to go to promote stronger collaboration around geographic locations and teams.

job_title: Area Fundraising Manager in Leicester, England
pros: I love working for Help for Heroes as there is a huge amount of drive, enthusiasm and determination to make things work so that our beneficiaries get first class support, everyone has a can do attitude.
cons: There's quite a lot of travelling involved in  my job and more than my fair share of evenings and weekends, but that's fundraising and we are encouraged to take the time back during the week.

review_title: Great place to work, an innovative environment where you can make a difference
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Downton, South West England, England
pros:
- Innovative environment with ability to make an impact on how things are done 
- Charity run with commercial acumen, with a good blend of skills & backgrounds within leadership team
- Capable, credible and personable CEO
- Personally I've had lots of great opportunities for personal professional development
cons:
- Not all sites are easy to reach on public transport
- I love being in an environment of continual improvement as things never get stale, however, this level of change isn't for everyone

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Downton, South West England, England
pros:
The work is interesting, and the Downton site is an informal fun environment. It's a good cause to work for and some great recovery stories.
Meeting beneficiaries is very rewarding and puts the work in perspective.
cons: Lack of communication between locations and business sectors. Poor management of work loads and team expertise is ignored and overridden by well meaning non professionals. The Charity finances are in decline. Staff leave regularly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Downton, South West England, England
pros: Casual dress, flexible working, local
cons: Worked in the IT dept. No one prepared to help or explain anything they just let you try and work it out yourself. Poor management within IT. Team members are allowed to swear and openly criticise the establishment. Most colleagues sit with ear phones in and listen to music so communication is non existant

job_title: Recovery Manager in North Yorkshire, England
pros: Real sense of purpose, with great teamwork and great public support. Opportunities to get involved in a wide range of services, activities and events and to meet some truly inspiring people. The Charity has a high profile, strong brand and ethos. I would definitely recommend working for Help for Heroes
cons: As a charity, pay and progression may not be as competitive as other sectors

review_title: We make the impossible possible for our Wounded, Injured and Sick service personnel, veterans and their families.
job_title: National Psychological Wellbeing Support in North Tidworth, England
pros: We make a difference, we live our values and we support those who need us, it's that simple!
cons: It's hard to take your Help for Heroes hat off at the end of each day and leave work behind - not necessarily bad but not always good.

job_title: Choir Lead in Salisbury, England
pros: I feel I am doing something worthwhile with an enduring legacy.  The  staff are supportive and the beneficiaries appreciative of my endeavours.
cons: Coming across people who have got to rock bottom is not easy but at least I am in a position to help them.

job_title: Supporter Care in Downton, South West England, England
pros:
The large teams mean there's many areas to move around to
The modern offices
The recovery centers are beautiful and I imagine a nicer place to work than the Downton office
cons:
Too many managers to a team. There's no need for 4-5 line managers for a team of 6
Big disconnect between every department
The higher staff members act as though they are above everyone else.
Too male and sports focused in their fundraising schemes

job_title: Area Fundraising Manager in Rochester, South East England, England
pros:
Passionate colleagues, supportive bosses, good salary and training.
Different to other charities in that they are more agile and love and listen to feedback. Promises for change are put into action wherever possible.
cons: Nothing that I can think of right now

review_title: An enjoyable and fulfilling place to work
job_title: Program Manager in South Tidworth, England
pros: Supported working environment, delivering meaningful  programs that genuinely change lives for the better.
cons: Lack of communication between different teams across the charity

review_title: North West, South and West Yorkshire
job_title: Area Fundraising Manager in Manchester, England
pros: Proud to see that the hard work that we put in is put to best use when helping the countries veteran community
cons: General public awareness is low due to the lack of media attention

review_title: A hard-working, spirited, passionate and committed organisation!
job_title: Videographer in Downton, South West England, England
pros: You'll be treated fairly and will be working with a talented and friendly team of like-minded people.
cons: There are limited opportunities for career development.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Tidworth, England
pros:
Fun
Able to stretch yourself
cons: Feels like your working for the army

job_title: Horticultural Therapist in Salisbury, England
pros: Flexible. Progressive, Innovative, Variety,
cons: There are none to speak of
